Congratulations to Jon Brockway of Westbrook on being named a Captain of the elite group America's Road Team, a program that educates the public about highway safety.  Jon has been a professional truck driver for 30 years and has accumulated more than 2.5 million accident-free miles.  I was delighted to meet Jon this week, and I am pleased that his commitment to safety is being recognized.
Delighted to welcome so many Mainers to Washington this afternoon who are here for the inauguration!
Sen. Collins was on CNN New Day this morning with Sen. Bill Cassidy to discuss their plan to provide better choices and increase access to affordable health care for all Americans.
A columnist for The New York Times makes a strong case in favor of the Cassidy-Collins Compromise to increase access to affordable health insurance for all Americans. Read the column below.

Just like the rest of America, I remember watching Mary Tyler Moore on television – in the Mary Tyler Moore Show and the Dick Van Dyke Show.  I was so fortunate to eventually come to know Mary as a friend, and as someone who dedicated her life to helping others – especially those living with Type 1 diabetes. As international chairman of JDRF, Mary testified at many of the Children’s Congresses that I held in the Senate.  Mary endured the ups and downs of Type 1 diabetes for so many years, but she never focused solely on her personal struggles with the disease.  Instead, she focused on finding a cure to help improve the lives of so many others, especially the children, who live with the serious complications from diabetes. We will honor Mary by continuing the work to which she committed so much of her time and energy.  She will be missed.

"Judge Gorsuch is an individual with great integrity and extraordinary intellect who has a deep respect for the law."      https://www.collins.senate.gov/newsroom/senator-collins%E2%80%99-statement-following-meeting-supreme-court-nominee-neil-gorsuch

Senator Susan Margaret Collins meets Dean Susan Margaret Collins, University of Michigan Gerald R. Ford School of Public Policy.

Delighted to meet with Mainers working to reduce substance abuse who were in D.C. for the Community Anti-Drug Coalitions of America National Leadership Conference.  We had a productive discussion on locally-based drug prevention programs and how these programs impact youth and adults across Maine.  Working together, we can effectively combat the opioid abuse epidemic that is causing so much harm throughout the country.

Excited to announce that AARP has endorsed the Senior$afe Act of 2017. This bipartisan legislation that Senator Claire McCaskill and I authored would put in place a commonsense plan to help protect American seniors from financial exploitation. Working together, we can protect older Americans from scams, which cost seniors an estimated $2.9 billion a year. Read more http://bit.ly/2lIaEuw

Wonderful to meet CJ Francis, a Passamaquoddy Tribe member who was named a “Champion for Change” by the Aspen Institute’s Center for Native American Youth.  The prestigious program selects only five Native American youths nationwide each year, and CJ was chosen for his impressive record of community engagement and leadership. http://bit.ly/2kNMrTK

At a Senate Aging Committee hearing I chaired, Philip Hatch of Portland provided thoughtful testimony on the IRS impersonation scam that targeted him and cost him thousands of dollars. Unfortunately, seniors lose an estimated $2.9 billion a year to scams like this. Seniors can report scams to the Committee’s Fraud Hotline at 1-855-303-9470, and they can help protect themselves from becoming victims by consulting the Committee’s anti-fraud resource guide: http://bit.ly/2l9lQkG

A child’s ZIP code should not determine his or her future success. Senator Martin Heinrich and I have reintroduced our 2Gen Act that focuses on addressing the needs of children and parents together to lift more people out of poverty.
Great to speak with WCSH’s Pat Callaghan in Portland today to discuss a variety of issues that are important to our country and to Maine.

Visited UNE’s Oral Health Center in Portland today. It was a terrific tour of such an impressive and advanced facility. It’s exciting to see education and practical oral treatment happening under one roof.

Enjoyed the opportunity to visit Pika Energy in Westbrook, which specializes in small wind turbines, solar, and energy storage.  The company has made great strides to advance clean and renewable energy technology, all while making its products right here in Maine from American materials.

Delighted to visit the YMCA in Bangor this morning, an important community resource that provides services to children, adults, and families.  Also enjoyed learning about the Second Wind Program, which organizes physical and social activities for seniors.

Enjoyed meeting with Muslim-American community leaders from Portland, Lewiston, and Auburn this week in my Portland office.
I had a great discussion in my Bangor office this week with a group from Mount Desert Island on a variety of issues affecting Maine and the country.

I was delighted to welcome Gorham resident and USM student Rona Sayed to my Portland office this week. Rona will be serving as an intern in my Portland office for the spring semester. She is an excellent student with a strong work ethic who will help me serve the people of Maine. Welcome Rona!
This week, I met with members from the Maine Academy of Family Physicians in my Bangor office.

I enjoyed talking with Betsy Rose, the President of the National Alliance on Mental Illness, Bangor, in my office this week.  Betsy is a high school classmate of my chief of staff, Steve Abbott. Both are proud Orono HS alums!

This week, I had a meeting with eight members of the group Mainers for Accountable Leadership in my Augusta office. The meeting was broadcast live on Facebook.  We discussed many issues important to Maine and to our country including health care, immigration, and national security.
Back in Washington D.C. today for votes. Enjoyed my discussion over video conference with Susan and Barbara of Auburn. Always great to connect with Mainers.
Wonderful to have dozens of Mainers in my Washington office this morning for coffee and donuts. It’s always a pleasure to welcome Mainers to our nation’s capital.

It is such an honor to receive the Veterans of Foreign Wars’ 2017 Congressional Award.  Maine has more veterans per capita than all but two other states in the country, and these brave men and women continue to give back to their communities even though they have already given so much.  I’m so proud to be an advocate for our veterans.

In case you missed it in today's Portland Press Herald:  “Senator Susan Collins of Maine may be best known for her willingness to cooperate with colleagues across the aisle and for her expertise on appropriations, but her non-political passion is all things food. She runs a weekly lunch group with her fellow Republicans, in which each member shows off his or her home-state specialty. She spends every weekend in front of the stove or oven, cooking up treats for her husband.  “Among his favorites is the meatloaf created by her mother, Pat. It has a few special twists: pungent dry mustard, horseradish and a topping of barbecue sauce rather than ketchup. ‘I grew up in a large family with five brothers and sisters,’ the senator told us. ‘The six of us all had very different food preferences, but on one thing we were unanimous: We all loved my mother’s meatloaf.’ ”

Veterans of Foreign Wars VFW honored Senator Collins this evening with the prestigious 2017 Congressional Award for her steadfast support of veterans and her commitment to strengthening America’s national security.    “It’s our honor to welcome Senator Collins, a life member of the VFW Auxiliary up in Caribou, Maine,” said National Commander Brian Duffy upon introducing Senator Collins.  “Senator Collins has a long record of looking out for you—the veterans of America.  Much needs to be done, and thanks to the leadership of Senator Collins, much will be done to help our veterans.”  “I am deeply honored to be named the recipient of this award,” said Senator Collins during her remarks.  “I am especially delighted to be here with the national and Maine leaders of the VFW Auxiliary.  Each of you, through your service to our nation in uniform and to our veterans through this great organization, makes me proud to be an advocate for veterans as well as a life member of the VFW Post in my hometown of Caribou.”
Thank you to all the Mainers who came by my office this morning for coffee. Great discussions with individuals and families from all over the state, from York County to Aroostook County.

Happy #ReadAcrossAmerica Day! And happy birthday to the inimitable Dr. Seuss! Reading is the best way for children to learn to love learning.  I have been so lucky to have the opportunity to visit more than 200 schools in Maine, and my favorite part of those visits is always reading books to children.

Excited to announce the addition of two new Mainers to my staff, both from Aroostook County: Elsa, from Stockholm, and Jacob, from Presque Isle. I am pleased that they will have the opportunity to be actively involved in the legislative process and to help me serve the citizens of Maine.

In case you missed it this week from Shawn Cunningham WAGM TV Personality: A big honor for Maine Senator Susan Collins. She was given the 2017 Congressional Award by the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States. The prestigious award is given to only one member of Congress each year in recognition of significant legislative contributions on behalf of those who have worn the uniform.
Had a great time watching the University of Maine's women's basketball team start their conference tournament in Portland today. Great win today, and good luck in the next round!
Enjoyed speaking with CBS Face The Nation's John Dickerson this morning.

Enjoyed attending the Maine Fishermen's Forum in Rockport this weekend and discussing the opportunities and challenges facing the fishing industry.  The annual event provides invaluable resources to the hardworking men and women who make a living off Maine's coast.  The fishing industry is an important part of Maine's heritage and its economy.  By working together, we can keep it strong.

An impressive, well-informed group of teens from Bangor Congregation Beth El met with me to discuss prison reform, LGBT and disability rights, and support of Israel.  Sarah Littlefield, Zivi Osher, Nate Seburn, Sam Koskie, and Noam Osher are visiting the capital with Rabbi Darah Lerner as part of a two-day educational program.
Justin Davis from South Berwick joins my DC staff.  A UMaine grad, he previously worked in my Bangor office.  Welcome, Justin!

I started this morning with many interesting discussions with Mainers over coffee and donuts in my Washington office.  The Goldhirsch family, for example, traveled from Trevett to attend the 2017 Kidney Patient Summit.  Sharon and Douglas Goldhirsch and their son, Rafael, were just a few of the dozens of Mainers who stopped by today.

Yahoo News’ Katie Couric sat down with me in my Washington office this morning for a wide-ranging, interesting discussion on many of the important issues facing our country.  We spoke about national security, my work on the Intelligence Committee, the need for health care reform, and my ongoing efforts to protect seniors from fraud.

Maine DOT Commissioner Dave Bernhardt testified at a hearing I chaired today, which focused on improving our nation’s infrastructure. His expert testimony provided helpful insight into the urgent need for increased investment in America’s transportation network.
Two great Katies! Katie Seelen, a hardworking member of my staff from Falmouth, ME, was named after Katie Couric.  Today, in Washington, the two got a chance to meet! #iwd2017

A bright, inspiring group of Husson University students met with me this morning to discuss the importance of supporting diversity on college campuses and the need to encourage our students to engage with their communities. Anastasia Lemitelamy, Jadae Bridges, Naomi Williams, Janice Osei, Zarena Isaac, Trang Le, Arditta Hasalami, and Aminat Gbadamosi are representatives from the University’s International Students Association, the African Students Association, and the United Students Association.
Katie Waeldner from Yarmouth and Lily Tedford from South Portland are representing Maine in the U.S. Senate Youth Program.  We spoke about their exciting week in Washington, DC.

I was truly honored to receive the National Parent Teacher Association’s 2017 Congressional Voice for Children Award. Maine PTA President Tracy Walker and Maine PTA Vice President Haley Tripp presented this award to me for my work to improve education and increase opportunity for all children.

Brewer native & Holy Cross grad Rowan Bost has joined my DC staff!  While a student at Brewer High School, Rowan served as a Senate page and played an important role in the day-to-day operations of the Senate.  Welcome back, Rowan!

Neal Williams from Greenville, the National Director of the New England Paralyzed Veterans of America, met with me to discuss our shared commitment to ensuring that our veterans receive the care they deserve.
Former Senator Elizabeth Dole spoke with me about the important work the Dole Foundation is doing to assist military families and caregivers.

I had a great conversation with my good friend, Democratic Senator Heidi Heitkamp of North Dakota, for her new podcast “The Hotdish.” I was delighted that she asked to interview me about the role of moderates in the Senate and where we can work together to solve the problems facing our country. Listen to the full interview here: http://bit.ly/2njN5gp
Happy 197th Birthday, Maine! To celebrate the occasion, Tim Stretton from Lewiston and Paige Eggleston from South Portland baked blueberry muffins with authentic Maine blueberries for our DC office.

As someone who benefited from the influence of mentors throughout my life, I am delighted to receive one of  Public Leadership Education Network’s Mentor Awards for encouraging the next generation of women leaders.
It was a pleasure to tour the Maine Indian Education facility, and meet Superintendent Linda McLeod and the hardworking staff there.

I had a terrific lunch at Steve and Tami Clark’s Nook and Cranny Restaurant in Baileyville with Dianne Tilton, Executive Director of the Downeast Institute, and Marianne Moore, the former mayor of Calais.

I always enjoy visiting Maine schools.  Yesterday, I visited Princeton Elementary School where I spoke at a student assembly and had the chance to read one of my favorite children’s books, “Antlers Forever!".
I joined Chuck Todd on Meet the Press this morning and discussed health care, the budget, and intelligence issues.
Bethany Zell, the program director for Pink Aroostook, met with me today about the importance of providing support and education on breast cancer issues in northern Maine and across the country.
Grandparents to the Rescue: Raising Grandchildren in the Opioid Crisis and Beyond

I was honored to be the first Senator to speak at the Lugar Diplomacy Series led by my good friend Senator Dick Lugar.  The series brings together leaders in Washington with ambassadors from around the world to help strengthen diplomatic relationships.

Dayna McCrum, Maine Future Farmers of America State President, and Natalie Hodgman, Maine FFA Member, shared with me their insights on Maine agriculture, including their experiences growing up and working on their family farms. Dayna’s family has a potato farm in Mars Hill, and Natalie’s family runs a sheep farm in Winterport.

At eight years old, Hannah Abbott, a current Cheverus High School junior, asked her Dad, “Can boys grow up to be Senators, too?”  She asked that question because her whole life, she had only known two women Senators.  Hannah is the daughter of my longtime Chief of Staff, Steve Abbott, and it has been such a pleasure to watch Hannah grow up with the confidence that she can conquer anything. I’m so proud that she has committed to the University of Maine Field Hockey team for the fall of 2018!! Congratulations, Hannah! Go Black Bears!

Bette Hoxie of Old Town provided compelling testimony at a Senate Aging Committee hearing I chaired on grandparents raising grandchildren due to the opioid crisis.  Bette raised her grandson, who is now 18 years old, and is currently caring for a 19-month-old boy.  She is also supporting other grandparents facing similar situations as the executive director of the Adoptive & Foster Families of Maine and the Kinship Program.

Organizations like the Bangor Area Recovery Network in Brewer are on the frontlines of the heroin and opioid abuse crisis that is taking a devastating toll on individuals, families, and communities.  It was great to meet with with members of BARN’s leadership to learn more about their important work, which brings hope, recovery, and healing to those struggling with substance abuse.

It was a pleasure to join Senator Angus S. King, Jr. in welcoming high school students from Cape Elizabeth Schools to the U.S. Capitol.  The AP Government class travels to D.C. annually to meet their Members of Congress, attend congressional hearings, and enhance their studies by seeing the legislative branch firsthand.

From the Senate floor this afternoon, I thanked members of the Maine National Guard, including former and current adjutant generals, General Bill Libby and General Doug Farnham, as well as our current guardsman stationed in Montenegro, Army Captain Nicolas Philips, for their work over the past ten years preparing Montenegro to join NATO.

From the Senate Floor today, I announced that I will cast my vote for Judge Neil Gorsuch to be a Justice of the United States Supreme Court. As the dozens of distinguished Maine attorneys who wrote to me in support of his nomination said: “In sum, during his tenure on the U.S. Court of Appeals, Judge Gorsuch distinguished himself as a judge who follows the law with no regard for politics or outside influence. We could not ask for more in an Associate Justice….” I agree, and I look forward to the confirmation of Judge Gorsuch.

Young athletes who train to represent our country at top levels of competition, and all who aspire to compete, should not fear victimization by trusted coaches and sports officials.  I was honored to stand beside Olympic gold medalist Dominique Moceanu and other former members of the U.S.A. Gymnastics national team who bravely shared their personal stories.  Together, we urged members in both parties to support the bipartisan legislation Senator Feinstein and I have introduced to help protect athletes from sexual abuse.
WATCH LIVE: Senator Collins chairs Senate Aging Committee hearing “The Arc of Alzheimer’s” with witness Maria Shriver.

The sea of purple that overflowed the room today for a hearing I chaired on the full arc of Alzheimer’s disease was truly inspiring.  Purple is the color worn by many passionate advocates, myself included, who seek to raise awareness about this terrible disease that affects millions of Americans.  We had an amazing panel of witnesses, including Maria Shriver, who founded the Women’s Alzheimer’s Movement.  Today’s sea of purple represented hope for families across our country, and it certainly made waves.

I had a robust discussion via video conference this week with Glen Brand of the Maine Sierra Club; Nicole Clegg from Planned Parenthood; Cynthia Phinney from AFL-CIO; Maine House Representative and former director of Equality Maine, Matt Moonen; and Mary Bonauto, a prominent lawyer who has argued before the U.S. Supreme Court, who joined us by phone. I appreciated the opportunity to talk with them about their concerns regarding Judge Gorsuch’s nomination.

It was an honor to attend the christening of the USS Thomas Hudner today, a ship built by the skilled and hardworking employees at Bath Iron Works. We were joined by Retired Navy Captain Thomas Hudner, who received the Medal of Honor for his valiant actions during the Battle of Chosin Reservoir in the Korean war.   I wish the USS Thomas Hudner fair winds and following seas, and may God always speed her safely home.

I was delighted to see Laura Benedict and her brother, Pete Benedict, the owner and general manager, respectively, of The Red Barn in Augusta.  Laura received the Restaurant Neighbor Award from the National Restaurant Association in recognition of her outstanding community service as well as the more than $2 million she has donated to charity.  It was a pleasure to congratulate her on this well-deserved honor.

Students from the University of Maine at Presque Isle's Criminal Justice Club shared with me their fascinating trip to the nation’s capital, where they participated in D.C. Police’s Ride-Along program.  It was wonderful to welcome them to my office, and I wish them all the best as they pursue careers in law enforcement.

The heroin and opioid abuse crisis is having a devastating effect on individuals, families, and communities in Maine.     The Portland Press Herald’s “Lost” series shines a light on many of these harrowing stories, including this one about the growing number of grandparents raising their grandchildren as a result of this epidemic.  I recently chaired a Senate Aging Committee hearing that recognized these grandparents and explored what can be done to assist them as they take on this unanticipated challenge motivated by their love of their grandchildren.

Dana Doran of Professional Logging Contractors, Andy Irish of Irish Family Logging in Peru, and Chuck Ames of SDR Logging in Sebec, met with me to discuss the challenges facing Maine’s logging and forest products industry.
WATCH LIVE: Senator Collins chairs hearing on preventing sexual assault and harassment at the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy

I enjoyed meeting with members of the Maine Jewish community, who were in D.C. for AIPAC's annual policy conference.  We discussed a number of key issues, including the importance of the United States’ relationship with Israel.

High school students Bailey Goss of North Berwick, Rebecca Huettner of Monson, Kelton Tanguay, and Meaghan Caruso of Gorham participated in the 4-H Program’s National Conference in D.C. I was delighted to meet with them in Washington and hear about their experiences growing up on their families’ farms.

As the Chairman of the Aging Committee, I have been warning seniors to beware of the “Say Yes” scam.  In this scheme, con artists call victims and ask “Are you there?’ or “Can you hear me?” and record the victims answering “Yes.”  The recording can then be used to authorize unwanted charges. If you receive a call from someone you do not know asking this type of question, simply hang up and call my Committee’s Fraud Hotline at 1-855-303-9470.  Watch this segment on WLBZ 2 to learn more about this scam.

I participated in a panel discussion in Lewiston on improving the affordability, accessibility, and quality of health care.  The event was hosted by Central Maine Medical Center and organized by the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network.  Our diverse group of panelists included Lori Parham of AARP Maine; David Thompson of Central Maine Healthcare; Gordon Smith of the Maine Medical Association; Dr. Dervilla McCann of Central Maine Healthcare & the American Heart Association; and Stretch Tuemmler, an ACS CAN volunteer and cancer survivor.

I had a great conversation with Ken Altshuler and Matt Gagnon on Newsradio WGAN in their Portland studio this morning.  We discussed a number of significant issues, including the opioid epidemic, Syria, health care, and my work as Chairman of the Senate Aging Committee to fight financial scams targeting seniors. Listen to the full interview here: http://bit.ly/2p3tNK4

I was delighted to welcome Lisbon native and University of Southern Maine student Abigayle Evans to my Lewiston office.  A graduate of Lisbon High School, Abigayle will be serving as an intern for the spring semester. It is always a pleasure to give Maine students an opportunity to become actively involved in the legislative process and to serve their state. Welcome, Abigayle!

It was a pleasure to talk with the students at Troy Central School about what it is like to serve as a United States Senator and to read one of my favorite books, Antlers Forever!, to the 1st and 2nd grade students.

A constituent meeting where I was the constituent. I enjoyed meeting with my Mayor Joseph Baldacci, my City Manager Cathy Conlow, and other Bangor leaders about the exciting work they are doing and how Bangor successfully utilizes federal investments.

Caitlin, a St. Dominic Academy student from Auburn, visited me in my Lewiston office this week. It was a pleasure to meet her and to participate in her school project, the ABCs of Maine. Thank you for choosing me as your “C,” and good luck on the project!

Jessica Mauer of Maine Council on Aging, Clair Berkowitz of Maine Children's Alliance, Abdulkerim Said of New Mainers Public Health Initiative, and Robyn Merrill of Maine Equal Justice Partners met with me in Portland.  We had a productive discussion, and they shared with me their thoughts and concerns on health care and Medicaid.

Chief U.S. District Judge Nancy Torresen and several other judges and clerks met with me and my chief of staff, Steve Abbott, in Portland this week.  We are blessed to have such a fine group of public servants in these important positions.

It was a pleasure to meet with Emerald Russell from Bangor in one of my Maine constituent service centers.  We discussed the current challenges facing our health care system and the need for mental health reform.
Our family celebrating my mother Pat Collins' 90th birthday in Caribou Saturday. Great time!

I always enjoy speaking with George Hale and Ric Tyler on WVOM in their Bangor studio.  We discussed a wide range of topics this morning, including scams that target seniors, immigration, and foreign policy.  Listen to the full interview here: http://www.wvomfm.com/play_window.php?audioType=Episode&audioId=7449919

Last year, Wayfair made an exciting expansion into our state, opening call centers in Bangor and Brunswick.  I was delighted to visit the Bangor customer service center and speak with the professional, hardworking employees there.  Wayfair sells a variety of home furnishings and décor products, including items from more than 60 Maine vendors.  By investing in Maine and creating good-paying, full-time jobs, Wayfair is helping to grow our economy and keep young people here.

Congratulations to the Maine School of Science and Mathematics on this incredibly impressive honor! The Limestone school was ranked the 10th best high school in the country for STEM and the 19th best high school overall. Go Penguins!

Over the past two weeks, I met with hundreds of Mainers and community leaders across the state on a variety of important issues.  I had the opportunity to participate in a health care forum at Central Maine Medical Center in Lewiston, visit elementary school students at Troy Central School, and speak with more than 75 employees at Wayfair’s new customer service center in Bangor.  Sign up for my newsletter to receive updates about my work as well as the exciting things happening in Maine and in Washington.  Read my latest newsletter here: http://bit.ly/2ottbjY

In today’s highly charged partisan atmosphere, it is more difficult than ever to find common ground.  Given how divided our country has become, I feel a special obligation to try to find a path forward on the many contentious issues we face.  It means so much to me that my work to bring people together and develop bipartisan solutions has been recognized today by The Lugar Center and Georgetown University.  Their objective analysis ranked me as the most bipartisan U.S. Senator for the fourth year in a row.

I was delighted to receive this thoughtful thank you note from Principal Glen Widmer and the students of Troy Central School. It was a pleasure to visit this impressive school at Principal Widmer’s invitation and to give Troy’s bright students a little advice: always do your best, work together, and have respect for others.

WATCH LIVE: Dr. Lenard Kaye, director of the University of Maine Center on Aging, testifies at U.S. Senate Special Committee on Aging hearing chaired by Senator Collins about the far reaching effects of loneliness and isolation on our seniors.
I had a great discussion with Senator Angus S. King, Jr. and Chuck Todd on Meet the Press this morning on the importance of bipartisanship.

Kellan Tilton and his Mom, Elizabeth Tilton, of Detroit, Maine, were in our nation’s capital to raise awareness of childhood cancer, support patients, and advocate for research.  Kellan, who is five years old, was born with a tumor in his spine and abdomen.   It was moving to hear Kellan’s inspirational story of perseverance in his fight against cancer, and it was a joy to welcome him to my office, where he lit up the room with his glowing personality and wonderful sense of humor. Thank you, Kellan, for sharing your story and a few of your jokes with me!

Congratulations to Gabrielle Cooper of Gardiner Area High School, who won Maine’s Poetry Out Loud competition and placed in the top 24 at the national competition in Washington! After hearing her impeccable recitation of “The Windhover,” a sonnet by Gerard Manley Hopkins, it was obvious why she did so well.  Best of luck to Gabrielle, who will be attending Dartmouth College this fall.
This morning, I joined George Stephanopoulos on ABC's This Week for an important discussion on health care. Watch below:

What a difference ten years makes! Grant Forbes, Hannah Flood, and Ben Burton were 2nd graders when I first met them in 2007 at Adams School in Castine. Thanks to the help of former principal Todd Nelson, we were able to meet again and take a picture with some of the photos from that day. It was a pleasure to hear about their exciting plans as they prepare to graduate high school: Grant will be attending Husson University, Hannah will be attending American University, and Ben will be attending Maine Maritime Academy. Congratulations, and good luck in college next year!

I was honored to give Maine Maritime Academy's 2017 Commencement address. From its founding 76 years ago, Maine Maritime Academy has attracted a special breed of student.  From the urgent need for merchant mariners during World War II to the 21st Century challenges of national security, the global economy, science, technology, energy, and the environment, Academy graduates have always risen to the challenge. Congratulations to the class of 2017, and may they always have fair winds and following seas!

I enjoyed meeting Maine Maritime Academy’s dedicated housekeeping staff prior to the Commencement ceremony last weekend.  It was wonderful to see the entire community coming together to wish the 2017 graduating class well as they embark on their careers

Katie Waeldner of Yarmouth and Bella Rossborough of Kennebunk are Maine’s impressive honorees for The Prudential Spirit of Community Awards. Katie, a senior at Yarmouth High School, developed a summer meal program for at-risk children, and Bella, a sixth grader at Middle School of the Kennebunks, raised awareness about the environmental impact of plastic bags. Both are exceptional students who have demonstrated what can be accomplished by participating and getting involved in your community. Congratulations, Katie and Bella! I can’t wait to see what you’ll do next.

I was honored to receive the Hero Award from JDRF for my work as the founder and co-chair of the Senate Diabetes Caucus.  It was particularly meaningful that Aiden Sweeney of Yarmouth presented me with the award.  I first met Aiden and his family in 2006 when I invited him to testify at a congressional hearing I chaired on type 1 diabetes.  It was wonderful to see him again along with his parents, Timothy and Caroline, and his siblings, Michael and Caitlin. With support from families like the Sweeneys and the strong advocacy of JDRF chapters across the country, I am confident that we will conquer this terrible disease.

I was delighted to join Senator Angus S. King, Jr. in welcoming Biddeford Middle School students to our nation’s capital. We are glad that these bright young Mainers had the chance to gain a deeper understanding of the legislative process by seeing it firsthand.

WATCH LIVE: Meg Callaway, project director of the Piscataquis Thriving in Place Collaborative, testifies at Senate Aging Committee hearing about age-friendly communities and initiatives chaired by Senator Collins.

Meg Callaway of Old Town testified today at a Senate Aging Committee hearing I chaired on initiatives to create age-friendly communities.  Meg is the project director of the Piscataquis Thriving in Place Collaborative, which provides critical services such as food, housing, and caregiver support to older adults living in Piscataquis County by coordinating a network of existing local resources.  Organizations like Meg’s can help us connect seniors with communities to make home not only a better place to grow up, but also a better place to grow old.

WATCH LIVE: Senator Collins speaks from the Senate floor on the Stop Illegal Trafficking in Firearms Act of 2017.  She introduced this legislation with Senator Patrick Leahy during National Police Week to help provide law enforcement officials with the necessary tools to stop the “drugs for guns” trade and deter straw purchasers and illegal weapons traffickers.

St. Lawrence President Bill Fox and I prior to commencement at which I received an honorary doctorate on Sunday, May 21.   Also pleased to see Caroline Seelen of Falmouth graduate magna cum laude. She was an intern in my office last summer.

I enjoyed meeting with Wendy Whiting and Karla Brannen, the Executive Director and President-Elect of the Maine Society of Certified Public Accountants, as well as Professor Dewey Martin, a member of the organization and professor at Husson University.  They were in Washington, D.C., for the American Institute of CPA’s national conference.  We had a substantive discussion on the important issue of tax reform.

I enjoyed meeting Dr. Elinore McCance-Katz, the intended nominee for Assistant Secretary for Mental Health and Substance Abuse at the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. We had a thorough discussion on ways we can work together to address mental illness and the opioid crisis, two very important issues affecting Maine and the nation. I look forward to hearing more about Dr. McCance-Katz’s ideas as she advances through the nomination process.
WATCH LIVE: Senator Collins, a senior member of the Appropriations Committee, questions leaders of the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps at a hearing on the President’s budget.

Good news! Secretary of Education Betsy DeVos has now agreed to review University of Maine at Presque Isle's Upward Bound grant application! UMPI's Upward Bound application was rejected because of small formatting errors, jeopardizing services to nearly 1,000 students.

Frank Anicetti, known affectionately as “Mr. Moxie,” was a larger-than-life figure who was beloved by the Lisbon community for his passion, vision, and magnetic personality.  As the owner of the iconic “Moxie Store” and a founder of the famous Moxie Festival, Frank had a profound effect on the town.  He will be deeply missed by his family, his countless friends, and the tens of thousands of people who attend Moxie Festival each year.

Elisabeth Kilroy and her brother Keegan Kilroy visited my DC office and updated me on her research regarding muscular dystrophy. She is currently pursuing a PhD at the University of Maine’s Graduate School of Biomedical Science and Engineering, where she works on identifying genes associated with muscular dystrophy, a terrible disease that affects both her brother and father. Her passion and drive are inspirational, and it was a pleasure to meet them both.

Dr. Lenard Kaye, the Director of the University of Maine Center on Aging, provided expert testimony at the Senate Aging Committee hearing I chaired on the various effects of isolation and loneliness in older Americans. Health deterioration is a major consequence of isolation, and researchers say prolonged isolation is comparable to smoking 15 cigarettes a day.

Penobscot Christian School seniors Reagan Paul, Joshua Guay, Ethan Smart, and Chara Grace Hamilton, accompanied by their chaperones Kelly Paul, Linda Smart, and school Headmaster Glenn Fisher, were in Washington, D.C., for the school’s senior trip. I was delighted to welcome them to my office and hear about their exciting week of events, which included a tour of the Capitol building from my staff. Congratulations on your upcoming graduation, and good luck on your future endeavors!

The Margaret Chase Smith Library in Skowhegan is one of our nation’s premier freestanding congressional libraries, and it was an honor to join the celebration of their 35th anniversary this morning.  The library’s hardworking directors, staff, and supporters have worked together in a collaborative spirit to pay the highest tribute to Senator Smith and her legacy. That legacy is, above all, a reminder of the obligation we all share to uphold the values and ideals of our nation.  Thanks to the Margaret Chase Smith Library, that message remains strong.

I was delighted to attend the Bates College 2017 Commencement and receive an honorary degree, the 12th I have received during my Senate service. Congratulations Bobcats, and best of luck as you prepare to embark on your careers!  Also, a special congratulations to my former intern Molly Ryan of Falmouth, who will be joining my staff in Washington, D.C., this summer.

Throughout America, we gather on this solemn day of gratitude.  In small towns and big cities, we honor those who died in the service of our country.  It was a privilege to join the Northern Maine Veterans Cemetery Memorial Day Ceremony in Caribou today to express our thanks for those who gave so much to defend the blessings of freedom.

I enjoyed the opportunity to speak with more than 100 Mainers at the Margaret Chase Smith Library’s Maine Town Meeting in Skowhegan on Friday.  The forum, which has been held annually since 1990, promotes discussion about issues important to Maine and our nation.  I delivered remarks about my efforts to foster bipartisanship and answered questions on topics that ranged from the Supreme Court to improving access to health care.

Actor and Lewiston native Patrick Dempsey has given back to his community in many ways, including through the Dempsey Center, a nonprofit organization he founded that offers free programs and services to assist those affected by cancer.  It was wonderful to see him again at Bates College’s 2017 Commencement, where he and I received honorary degrees as did children's advocate Geoffrey Canada and art historian Wanda Corn.

Volunteer firefighters play a critical role in helping to ensure the safety of our communities and the well-being of our neighbors.  In Maine, more than 90 percent of firefighters are volunteers. The opioid and heroin abuse epidemic is taking a growing toll on Maine families.  With so many parents struggling with addiction, grandparents are increasingly coming to the rescue and assuming the role of primary caregivers for their grandchildren.  This month’s AARP Bulletin examined this often overlooked trend.  The article featured a description of a recent Aging Committee hearing I chaired on this growing phenomenon and the legislation I introduced to support these grandparents.

Tamara Ranger, the 2017 Maine Teacher of the Year, recently met with me in my DC office. Her dedicated work at Skowhegan Area Middle School helps her students realize their full potential. Tamara exemplifies the importance of our teachers, and I’m proud to have recently led a bipartisan resolution to honor our educators and to celebrate National Teacher Appreciation Week. Thank you Tamara, and all our teachers for supporting, inspiring, and encouraging children across our country.

Congratulations to NCAA Division 1 long jump national champion Kate Hall of Casco! As a proud life member of Caribou’s VFW Post, I was honored to speak at the Veterans of Foreign Wars, Department of Maine’s 97th State Convention. When our service members return home, we have an obligation to welcome them all the way home with the health care, educational opportunities, and support they earned and deserve, and the VFW and Auxiliary are always front and center, ready to lend a hand.

I enjoyed delivering the graduation address for Sacopee Valley High School. Congratulations to the Class of 2017!  You have worked hard, and the gate of opportunity is open – don’t be afraid to stride through it with confidence, take risks, or follow your dreams.

The National Institutes of Health (NIH) conducts groundbreaking biomedical research to conquer devastating diseases that affect every family. Last week, I was pleased to join a bipartisan group of my colleagues to visit the NIH campus and meet with NIH Director Francis Collins to learn more about the exciting advancements they are making. As Dr. Steven Rosenberg, chief of the Surgery Branch at National Cancer Institute’s Center for Cancer Research, said, "We are trying not to practice yesterday's medicine, but to create tomorrow's."
Happy 93rd Birthday to President George H.W. Bush, a great American with a lifetime of service and dedication to our country!

It was great to speak with them as well as the many other Mainers who came by.

Our nation mourns the sailors who perished aboard the USS Fitzgerald in a terrible accident off the coast of Japan.  Their tragic loss is a reminder of the dangers faced by our service members every day.  I am proud of the heroic efforts of the ship’s crew who worked to prevent further flooding and to prevent the ship from sinking. I'm also grateful for the support provided by Japanese responders.  It is important for the Navy to conduct a thorough investigation to ensure a similar incident never occurs again.

Andrew Cotton of Alfred and Syeda Washima Fairoz of Biddeford are participating in the University of Southern Maine’s Upward Bound program.  Upward Bound helps hundreds of high school students across our state access higher education and unlock their full potential. I wish Andrew and Syeda all the best as they prepare for college.

It was an honor to be recognized as the 2017 Legislator of the Year by the American Ambulance Association. I am grateful for the brave men and women of our emergency personnel, who demonstrate commitment, courage, and skill as they work around the clock to protect our communities.

On Independence Day, we give thanks to that founding generation of Americans who risked all to overcome tyranny so that they, and all the generations to come, could live in freedom.   We also express gratitude for the many Americans since who have answered the call to serve and sacrifice for the ideals of our founding.   To be an American, whether by birth or by choice, is a precious gift.  As citizens of this great nation, we can all be proud of our heritage and confident in our future. The principles of July 4, 1776, still speak to us and to all humanity.  Now, as then, we pledge our lives and honor to freedom's defense. And we will always believe that freedom is the hope and the future of every land.

The Fourth of July is a wonderful day of jubilation.  This year, I enjoyed participating in Eastport’s 4th of July Grand Independence Day Parade, Maine's largest Fourth of July parade.  I was delighted to join thousands of Mainers in celebrating 241 years of our great country and recognizing this year's theme: Honor those who serve.

The new breakwater at the Port of Eastport is officially open! I was delighted to join Senator Angus S. King, Jr., Congressman Bruce Poliquin, and the residents of Eastport to celebrate at the ribbon-cutting ceremony.

After seeing the attention to detail and skilled workmanship that is used to produce each bat, it is no wonder that they are in such high demand.

I had an excellent meeting with members of the Moosehead Lake Regional Economic Development Committee at the StressFree Moose Pub/Cafe in Greenville.  We discussed ways to support small businesses, create jobs, and grow the economy of the Moosehead Lake Region.  I also spoke with local business owners about the importance of improving health care.

Congratulations on your new role, Lt. Gen. Jokic, and welcome to NATO!

Congratulations to Lucas Oldershaw, Jacob Goslant, Noah Mains, Brian Mank, and Brandon Mank of Jordan-Small Middle School in Raymond for their outstanding achievement in the SIFMA Stock Market Game Capitol Hill Challenge. Willie left an indelible mark on the City of Bangor and the State of Maine. A leader who was committed to bettering her community, Willie worked to advance numerous civic institutions throughout her life. In addition to being a model of civic leadership, Willie was a trailblazer as the first woman to chair the United Way of Eastern Maine’s Board of Directors and become a member of the Eastern Maine Medical Center Board of Trustees.   Willie and her beloved husband, ‘Pappy,’ were close friends of my family for many years. They had raised their children on Cedar Street, and I enjoyed seeing Willie when she returned to the neighborhood for the annual Christmas Coffee. Last fall, when my mother was visiting me, Willie came to my home for lunch and, as always, was the life of the party.”  Willie will long be remembered for her dedication to the City of Bangor. Her passing is a loss to the countless individuals whose lives she touched through her tireless service to the community and through her boundless optimism.
Happy Birthday to my former colleague Barbara Mikulski! She is an extraordinary role model, a wonderful mentor, and a close friend.

I nominated Sophie Frantz of Portland to the U.S. Senate Page Program, and it was a pleasure to welcome her to my Washington, D.C., office for her first day of this exciting program. This investment will help spur the advancement of treatments, means of prevention, and cures for diseases that affect nearly every American family.

They updated me on homelessness statistics and shelter statuses in Maine, and we discussed our shared priority of helping Americans break the terrible cycle of poverty.

I enjoyed meeting with two of our state’s many incredible teachers: Karen MacDonald, the 2014 Maine Teacher of the Year, and Becky Tapley, the 2016 Hancock County Teacher of the Year. Karen and Becky teach at King Middle School and Brooklin School, respectively.  It was great to hear their perspectives on education policies that are significant to Maine.

The Purple Heart is a reminder that freedom is a gift purchased at the greatest possible price.  Just as the Purple Heart Medal has held a special meaning to its millions of recipients and family members, it also has special significance to my family.  My father, Don Collins, is a World War II veteran who was wounded twice during the Battle of the Bulge.  He earned two Purple Hearts and the Bronze Star.  I am delighted that Congress recently passed my resolution marking today as National Purple Heart Recognition Day to honor all of the brave men and women who have made tremendous sacrifices to defend our nation.  Thank you all for your service.

Veterans deserve convenient access to the high-quality health care that they have earned through their service.  I am pleased that Congress passed the VA Choice and Quality Employment Act, which includes my provisions to authorize leases for Community-Based Outpatient Clinics across the country, including in Portland, and ensure Northern Maine veterans who received local health services through the ARCH program continue to have access to care in their communities under the Choice program. I look forward to it being signed into law.

Glen Campbell’s songs struck a chord in the hearts of millions of Americans.  In addition to his music, Glen will always be remembered as a courageous advocate in the fight against Alzheimer’s disease.  I had the joy of meeting Glen at a hearing I chaired four years ago.  While Glen did bring his guitar with him to Capitol Hill, his primary purpose was not to perform.  Instead, he and his family stepped into the spotlight to speak out on behalf of the growing number of Americans who are suffering from Alzheimer’s.  We will honor his legacy by continuing to support investments in biomedical research to find an effective means of prevention, treatment, or a cure for this devastating disease.

Today we mourned the passing of Old Town native Dick MacPherson.  He was a hall of fame coach, a great family man, and a proud son of Maine. He had a joy for life that was infectious, and he will be missed.

Kaley Norsworthy of Fort Fairfield and Isabelle Wright of Mars Hill are members of Future Farmers of America. L.L.Bean is an iconic Maine company that was built on the foundation of the Maine Hunting Shoe more than a century ago. Sixteen years have passed, but the memory of September 11, 2001, remains as vivid as if it were yesterday.  Those of us old enough to remember each have our own recollections of where we were and what we were doing as the horrifying attacks began to unfold.  We share the still-powerful emotions of shock, anger, and grief.  On the evening of that terrible day, members of Congress gathered on the steps of the U.S. Capitol.  With tears in our eyes and sorrow in our hearts, together we sang, “God Bless America.”  The emotions of shock, anger, and grief were joined by unity and resolve.    Today, that moment remains my most enduring memory.  The sense of unity, resolve, and patriotism that swept over us as we sang was a source of strength in the challenges we faced.  In Maine, we remember Robert and Jackie Norton of Lubec, a devoted retired couple who boarded Flight 11 to celebrate a son’s wedding on the West Coast.  We remember James Roux of Portland, an Army veteran and a devoted father, on Flight 175 for a business meeting in California.  We remember Robert Schlegel of Gray who was celebrating his recent promotion to the rank of Commander in the United States Navy, and still settling into his new office at the Pentagon, an office that is believed to be the point of impact for Flight 77.  We remember Stephen Ward of Gorham, who was working on the 101st floor of the North Tower that terrible morning.  On this solemn anniversary, we join all Americans in remembering each of the nearly 3,000 lives lost that day – lives of accomplishment, contribution, and promise.  Each loss leaves a wound in the hearts of families and friends that can never be fully healed.  And we honor the heroes of that day.  We still are moved by the selfless courage of men and women on Flight 93 who wrestled that plane to the ground, sacrificing their lives so that others might live.  We are inspired by the firefighters and police officers at the World Trade Center who continued to climb upward in rescue even as the Twin Towers were coming down.  We pay tribute to the first responders, the military personnel, and the civilians who rushed into the smoke and flames at the Pentagon to lead others to safety.  We express our gratitude to those who have given so much to defend our nation against terrorism, the men and women of our armed forces.    September 11th was not just a day of personal tragedy.  It was an attack on the United States, an attack on freedom, an attack on civilization.  We must never forget what was lost and what remains at stake.  We must pledge to do all that we can to prevent future attacks.  The fundamental obligation of government is to protect its people.  Since September 11th, we have done much to meet that obligation.  In what seemed like a moment, September 11th was transformed from a day like any other into one that, forever, will stand alone.  The loss we relive reminds us of the value of all that we must protect.  The heroism reminds us of the unconquerable spirit of the American people.  Our accomplishments remind us that we can meet any challenge with decisive action.  As long as we keep the meaning of this day of remembrance in our hearts, we will meet the challenges that lie ahead.

It is a special pleasure to have the opportunity to commemorate Veterans Day in Freedom, Maine, a town whose very name celebrates the great gift we have been given by our veterans and those who serve today.  On this sacred day, we honor those who paid the ultimate price, whether they lie at rest in foreign lands or in their hometowns.  We honor those who lived beyond their years of military service but who have since passed on.  We honor those who remain missing and pledge that they never will be forgotten.  And we honor those veterans who are with us today.  We owe them all a great debt.  It is estimated that some 48 million Americans have served in uniform since the founding of our nation.  Today, more than 20 million veterans live among us, including more than 116,000 right here in Maine.  To put that in perspective, Maine has more veterans per capita than all but two of the other states in the country.  We are proud of our State’s contributions to protecting our nation.  My father, Don Collins, is a World War II veteran who was wounded twice during the Battle of the Bulge in Europe. He earned two Purple Hearts and the Bronze Star.  It was from him that I first learned to honor and respect our veterans.  We owe our veterans so much, and repay that debt in part, but only in part, with the gratitude we express on Veterans Day.  As a nation, we must also repay our debt with the health care, rehabilitation services, and educational and employment opportunities our veterans have earned through their service to our country.  I am committed to ensuring that the government keeps that sacred obligation.
